summary: Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that originates from bone-forming cells. It is the most common primary bone cancer in children and young adults, and also occurs in the elderly, often associated with underlying bone pathology like Paget's disease. It can also arise from soft tissues (extraskeletal osteosarcoma).
causes: Infestation with the parasite Spirocerca lupi (esophageal osteosarcoma)
risk_factors: Hereditary predisposition (e.g., in St. Bernard dogs)
Exposure to ionizing radiation (implicit from leukemia causes, though not explicitly stated for osteosarcoma)
Prior chemotherapy (implicit from leukemia causes, though not explicitly stated for osteosarcoma)
symptoms: Swelling or a lump near the affected bone
Easy bruising or bleeding (general cancer symptom)
Swollen lymph nodes or spleen (general cancer symptom)
diagnosis: CT scan (for bony anatomy, cortex integrity, fracture, ossification, calcification)
MRI scan (for soft tissue and medullary cavity)
Symmetrical widening of the periodontal ligament space (in jaw osteosarcoma)
Genetic and chromosomal testing (implicit from related genes)
treatments: Osteoclast inhibitors (e.g., alendronate, pamidronate) for pain and fracture risk reduction
Filgrastim or pegfilgrastim (for white blood cell and neutrophil counts)
Radiation therapy (mentioned in clinical trials context)
